subject: Photography
title: Astrophotography: Shooting the Stars
description: A 60-second lesson on Astrophotography: Shooting the Stars.

hook.text: The Milky Way stretches across the sky, invisible to city eyes. A camera can capture what you can't see.

buildup.text: Astrophotography uses long exposures and high ISO to record starlight that's too faint for human vision.

discovery.text: The '500 Rule' helps: divide 500 by focal length to find the maximum exposure time before stars trail.

twist.text: Light pollution is the enemy. The best locations are hours from any city ‚Äî remote, dark, and often cold.

climax.text: Astrophotography reveals a sky most people have never seen ‚Äî a universe hiding just above the streetlights.

punchline.text: The camera sees stars your eyes can't. Just point up.

quiz.question: What does the '500 Rule' help astrophotographers determine?
options: Maximum exposure time before stars start to trail
